blogs.title: Kenyan Political Giant Raila Odinga Dies at 80 in India
blogs.body:
Former Kenyan Prime Minister and veteran opposition leader Raila Amolo Odinga has died at the age of 80 after suffering a cardiac arrest while undergoing treatment in India. Odinga, a towering figure in Kenyan and African politics for decades, collapsed during a morning walk at an Ayurvedic treatment facility in Koothattukulam, Kerala, on Wednesday morning. His death creates an immediate and profound leadership vacuum in Kenya's political opposition.

Indian media reported that medical staff rushed Odinga to Devamatha Hospital in the nearby Ernakulam district, but doctors pronounced him dead shortly after 9:50 a.m. local time. Hospital sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the cardiac event to news agencies, noting resuscitation efforts failed. Odinga had been in India for specialized Ayurvedic treatment, a facility his daughter had previously visited for her vision. The Kenyan Embassy in Delhi is coordinating efforts for the repatriation of his body.

Odinga's nearly five-decade career defined modern Kenyan democracy. Born in 1945, the son of Kenya's first Vice-President, he courageously endured years of detention without trial under the single-party regime of Daniel arap Moi for his pro-democracy activism. He served as the Prime Minister of Kenya from 2008 to 2013 in a power-sharing arrangement that ended post-election violence.Despite running for the presidency unsuccessfully five times—most recently in 2022—he remained a hugely influential leader, consistently demanding electoral justice and constitutional reform.

Leaders across the globe immediately expressed shock and grief at the news. Kenyan President William Ruto led the nation in mourning, while former Chief Justice David Maraga called Odinga a "patriot, a pan-Africanist, a democrat and a leader who made significant contributions to democracy in Kenya and in Africa," posting his sentiments on X.Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi described Odinga as a "towering statesman" and a "cherished friend of India."

Odinga’s passing leaves the Azimio la Umoja One Kenya Coalition Party without its unifying force ahead of the 2027 general elections. Known affectionately by supporters as "Baba," his populist rallies mobilized masses, demonstrating his powerful connection to ordinary Kenyans. "Kenya has lost one of its most formidable leaders who shaped the trajectory of our beloved country," Maraga added. Political analysts suggest Odinga’s death will trigger a rapid realignment of political forces, challenging the stability of the current political landscape and the recent truce he struck with the government.

blogs.title: Jesus Fails to Return
blogs.body:
The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness, led by popular televangelist Prophet David Owuor, has dismissed claims circulating on social media suggesting that the world would end on Saturday, August 2, 2025.

In a strongly worded statement, the church described the doomsday predictions linked to the church and it’s founder as false, baseless, and malicious. The church asserts that the statements were deliberately crafted to tarnish the reputation of both Prophet Owuor and the ministry.

The statement, signed by Senior Archbishop Michael Nieswand, emphasized that the Bible is clear on matters concerning the end of the world, citing Matthew 24:36, which states that “no one knows the day or hour when the Messiah will return.”

“We, the leadership and congregation of the Ministry of Repentance and Holiness, strongly denounce the recent spread of false and misleading information about the world ending on August 2, 2025,” the statement read.
“These claims are false, baseless, malicious, and intended to harm not only the reputation of the Prophet of the Lord, David Owuor, and the Ministry of Repentance and Holiness, but also the unity and testimony of our church.” the statement continued.

The ministry further urged media houses, bloggers, and social media users to verify information before publishing or sharing it, warning against the spread of misinformation that could mislead the public and cause unnecessary panic.

“As believers, we are called to pursue truth, peace, and righteousness. Let us not be quick to spread gossip, but instead be diligent in prayer, discernment, and unity,” the church noted.

Reports predicting the end of the world began circulating on various online platforms in late June 2025, claiming that Prophet Owuor had prophesied global destruction. The rumors quickly gained traction, sparking debate among Kenyans and international followers of the preacher.Prophet David Owuor, a controversial yet influential religious figure, is widely known for his large evangelistic rallies and trademark white suits. Among his followers, he is revered as a miracle worker and a man who has experienced several supernatural encounters.
The ministry reiterated that its teachings remain rooted in biblical repentance and holiness

blogs.title: Hell’s Nun
blogs.body:
A video showing a senior Catholic nun repeatedly slapping a younger nun at St. John's Rakwaro Minor Seminary in Homa Bay has gone viral, prompting an official response from the church and an internal investigation. The footage, widely circulated on social media, shows the older nun repeatedly striking the younger sister, who is heard asking, “Why are you beating me, Sister?” The incident is believed to have occurred on September 5, 2025.
On September 8, the Franciscan Sisters of St. Joseph (FSJ), also known as the Asumbi Sisters, released a statement addressing the incident. The Superior General, Sister Mary Goretty Ochieng, called the action a "personal failing" that "does not represent the values" of their congregation. Sister Ochieng added that violence of any kind is contrary to their core principles of "joyful love and compassion."

The FSJ leadership has assured the public that they are addressing the matter internally to ensure the “dignity and well-being” of their members. The Association of Sisterhoods of Kenya (AOSK) has also called for calm as the matter is handled through the appropriate internal channels.

Meanwhile, Kenyans on social media expressed shock and condemnation, with many calling for external investigations and stricter accountability within religious institutions. The debate has widened into concerns about safeguarding vulnerable members of the Church.

Abuse scandals have long troubled the Catholic Church globally. Since the early 2000s, inquiries in the United States, Ireland, Germany, and Australia have uncovered widespread physical, emotional, and sexual abuse, often concealed by Church authorities.

In Africa, cases have been less public but are surfacing more frequently. Reports from Kenya, Uganda, and Nigeria highlight abuses tied to power imbalances in seminaries and convents. Advocates say many victims remain silent, citing stigma, fear, and deference to religious authority.

blogs.title: “No bans from us” Nacada says
blogs.body:
The National Authority for the Campaign Against Alcohol and Drug Abuse (NACADA) has clarified that no bans have been introduced on alcohol advertising, online sales, home deliveries, or celebrity endorsements. The clarification follows public speculation after the launch of the National Policy for the Prevention, Management and Control of Alcohol, Drugs, and Substance Abuse earlier this week.

In a statement issued on Thursday, NACADA Chief Executive Officer Dr. Anthony Omerikwa emphasized that the policy document unveiled by the Cabinet Secretary for Interior and National Administration, Hon. Kipchumba Murkomen, is currently a set of policy recommendations and not enforceable law.

“We wish to emphasize that no bans have been introduced. These measures are currently policy recommendations, not law,” said Dr. Omerikwa. “Their inclusion aims to initiate legal and regulatory reviews, subject to proper procedures.”

Dr. Omerikwa noted that the policy is intended to serve as a guiding framework for addressing alcohol and substance abuse in Kenya. The next steps, he explained, will involve developing a multi-sectoral implementation framework that will engage key stakeholders from government agencies, industry players, civil society organizations, and the public.

He further assured that any proposals requiring legal backing will undergo a comprehensive and transparent review process, including wide-ranging consultations and public participation.
NACADA urged both the media and the public to interpret the policy as a roadmap rather than an enforcement directive, cautioning against misinformation about supposed bans or restrictions.

According to the authority, the goal of the policy is to protect young people from the dangers of alcohol and substance abuse, reduce harm, and promote a healthier and more productive society.
“The policy provides a foundation for constructive dialogue and coordinated national action on drug and substance abuse prevention,” NACADA concluded.

blogs.title: Blood Moon
blogs.body:
Tonight, Kenyans will have their eyes turned skywards as the country witnesses one of nature’s most mesmerizing spectacles. A total lunar eclipse, popularly known as the “blood moon’’ will grace the Kenyan Skies from 8:31 p.m., when the Earth’s shadow will completely cover the moon, painting it deep red. This phenomena will be visible across many places in the country with exceptional viewing places especially known for star gazing , among them the Mt. Kenya National Park where this reader joined natures’ enthusiasts among them academicians for a week long camp in anticipation of this historical, once in a lifetime occurence.

Astronomy enthusiasts and curious onlookers started flocking to the high-altitude region of Mount Kenya National Park at dawn a week ago where clear skies promise an unobstructed view of the celestial event.
“This is one of those moments where science meets beauty,” says Dr. Miriam Kilonzo, an astrophysicist at the University of Nairobi. “A total lunar eclipse like this occurs only when the Earth perfectly aligns between the sun and the moon, casting its shadow across the lunar surface. The reddish glow happens because sunlight is refracted through the Earth’s atmosphere. It’s like watching every sunrise and sunset on Earth reflected on the moon.

According to the Kenya Space Agency, the eclipse will begin at 6:28 p.m. with the penumbral phase, but the real show starts at 8:31 p.m. when the total eclipse begins. The moon will reach its darkest and most striking point around 9:12 p.m., before gradually returning to normal by 11:55 p.m.
For locals in the foothills of Mount Kenya, the event has stirred excitement and curiosity. Samuel Mwangi, a tour guide in Nanyuki, said many visitors have booked night hikes and camping experiences to catch the rare view. “We’ve had tourists coming from as far as Mombasa and even Uganda,” he said. “People want to see the blood moon from the highest point possible. It’s a great experience.”

But beyond the scientific wonder, cultural interpretations still thrive. Mama Gakenia, an elderly woman from Meru County, smiled as she shared her traditional view. “When the moon turns red, our grandparents used to say it’s the earth cleansing itself as a sign of renewal.’’

Experts have advised that no special glasses are needed for viewing as it is safe to watch with the naked eye. However, binoculars or telescopes can enhance the spectacle.
Warm clothing is recommended for those planning to stay outdoors, especially in high-altitude areas where temperatures drop after sunset.

As Kenyans gather under the open sky, the red moon serves as a reminder of the shared wonder that binds humanity across science, culture, and curiosity. “Moments like this connect us,” Dr. Kilonzo reflected. “They remind us how beautiful our universe can be.”

blogs.title: Regional Wrap- up
blogs.body:
Thursday, October 10, 2025

Dodoma, Tanzania.

Preparations are underway for the October general elections, with President Samia Suluhu Hassan cleared by the electoral body to defend her seat. Her leadership has drawn both praise and criticism. Supporters commend her for restoring stability and improving Tanzania’s global image, while critics argue that the race is far from fair.
“President Samia is practically competing against herself,” said Dr. Peter Mukawimwana, a political analyst in Dar es Salaam. “Her main challenger, Tundu Lissu of the Chadema Party, is facing treason charges, making it difficult for the opposition to campaign freely.”

Kampala,Uganda

Long serving leader Yoweri Museveni has once again been cleared by the National Resistance Movement (NRM) to contest for another term, setting up yet another confrontation with opposition leader Robert Kyagulanyi, popularly known as Bobi Wine.
The political climate remains tense, with reports of violence and intimidation at opposition rallies. The situation worsened this week when two Kenyan human rights activists, Bob Njagi and David Oyoo, were reportedly abducted in Kampala. The two had been en route to meet Bobi Wine when their vehicle broke down. Witnesses allege that men believed to be police officers took them away.Their disappearance has sparked outrage among Kenyan activists, who have threatened demonstrations. “We just want them back home safely,” said Lydia Oyoo, sister to one of the missing men. The Kenyan Ministry of Foreign Affairs remains tight-lipped over the grievious human righys violations.

ADDIS, Ethiopia

Meanwhile, in Ethiopia, hope is rising following the official launch of the Grand Renaissance Dam, Africa’s largest hydroelectric project. Experts say the dam will significantly boost energy production and regional trade.
“This project is a symbol of progress,” said Dr. Tesfaye Alemu, an energy researcher in Addis Ababa. “It shows that East Africa can still move forward, even amid political challenges.”

blogs.title: Historic Israel-Hamas Ceasefire Deal Takes Effect, Hostages Freed
blogs.body:
A long-awaited ceasefire agreement between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas has taken effect, bringing the first significant pause in the devastating two-year conflict in Gaza and leading to the release of all remaining living Israeli hostages. The deal, brokered through intense international mediation, marks a critical initial step in a broader peace plan.

The truce, the first phase of a broader 20-point peace plan unveiled by US President Donald Trump, saw all 20 living Israeli hostages returned on Monday, days after Israel's cabinet formally approved the arrangement. In exchange, Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners and detainees.

The agreement mandates a significant surge in humanitarian aid, with up to 600 trucks per day expected to enter Gaza, according to the White House plan. However, the fragile truce faced an immediate test on Tuesday when Israel halved the aid flow, citing delays in the return of the remains of deceased hostages by Hamas.
The sentiment of cautious relief and high stakes was palpable. Khalil al-Hayya, a senior Hamas official and lead negotiator, reflected this during a televised speech, saying, “We declare today that we have reached an agreement to end the war and the aggression against our people.” Meanwhile, families of the hostages expressed "overwhelming joy and relief" at the news of their loved ones' return, according to the Hostages and Missing Families Forum.

The conflict, which erupted on October 7, 2023, following a massive attack by Hamas on southern Israel, has led to a major Israeli military offensive in the Gaza Strip. The operation has resulted in widespread destruction and the deaths of tens of thousands, overwhelmingly Palestinians, according to Gaza authorities. Previous attempts at sustained ceasefires, including one in November 2023 and another in March 2025, failed to hold.

This breakthrough deal, mediated primarily by the US, Egypt, and Qatar, requires a partial withdrawal of Israeli troops to new agreed-upon lines within Gaza, focusing on the immediate exchange of captives and prisoners and a massive boost in aid before tackling thornier issues like Hamas disarmament and future governance of the enclave. The US has committed to sending approximately 200 troops to Israel to help monitor the ceasefire and facilitate aid delivery.
